bibl.title: Letter from James Carroll to Howard A. Kelly, June 23, 1906

div1.p: Carroll comments on Kelly's manuscript. He corrects errors of fact, and objects to the attention given Reed to the detriment of himself, Lazear, and the rest of the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from James Carroll to Howard A. Kelly, June 23, 1906

opener.dateline:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
June 23, 1906.

div1.p:
I have
noticed one or two additional
errors of fact and date
in your little book and
I readily call your attention
to them as you requested
because I know that with
you the truth will prevail
above all other considerations.

I desire particularly to
call your attention to the
remark in the par. at the
foot of p. 133, that the ex-
periment on me “was followed by
2.
eleven others, of which nine
were negative and two
positive.” That would make
three positive cases, while
as a matter of fact there
were only two, myself and
the soldier x - y, and we were
the two last of these experi-
ments, the first nine being
negative, for the reason
that in those cases, all
the mosquitoes, with a
single exception, had been
kept a shorter period than
12 days after biting a patient.
The exception was a single
insect that had bitten a
very mild case in the 5th
day of the disease, 13 days earlier.

The same mosquito that was applied to me
12 days after its contamination was also one of
those applied four days later to Case No 11
and he also was infected and came down
with yellow fever. This proved confirmatory
of the source of my infection so that in cases
10 and 11 we have a demonstration of the
mosquito theory and confirmation of it,
all the work of Lazear, during Reed's absence
in the United States. For proof of these assertions
see pp 10 and 19 of the Preliminary Note, which was
written by Reed and presented by him to the
4.
Am. Pub. Health Ass'n at Indianapolis, Oct. 27, 1900.
Is there anything doubtful in the working of
the 2d Conclusion at the end of the paper?
The discovery was made by Lazear in my own
person and it was confirmed immediately
in a second case. Is it fair, is it just then
to single out Reed and give to him the sole
credit of a discovery that was made while he
was more than a thousand miles away? On the
evening of the 3d of August, Reed, Lazear and
I agreed to be bitten. On the following
morning Reed sailed for the United States,
without a word of explanation so far as I knew
5.
He was given carte blanche by Gen Sternberg
to go and come as he pleased. He returned
in October to verify and write up the
results reported to him by mail. When
he wrote the letter you cite on p. 141 of
your book, his recollection of the facts
was evidently less clear than with
those who had been through the fun.
I hope you will not think unkindly
of me for mentioning these facts for I have
a wife and family of seven children in
whose interest it is my duty to speak the truth.
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
6.
Notwithstanding promises since 1900, the
only recognition accorded to me was the
waving of the age limit to permit me as a
Contract (Act'g Asst.) Surgeon, to take the ex-
amination for the regular service, after I had
served continuously twenty-eight and a half
years with a clear record, 24+ years in the
regular army. This reminds me of an error
on p. 255. I have been in the Army since January
1874 continuously.

Let us have the truth. The efforts of
a few individuals to give the sole credit
to Reed is wrong in principle and in fact.
7.
The credit belongs to the Board. If it were to
be given to a single individual it should
go to Lazear. I enclose a copy of the
Preliminary Report referred to.
div1.closer:
Yours very truly, James Carroll. Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
1406 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Md.
